gameframework.motion.blocking

Class MoveBlockerRulesApplierDefaultImpl

  • java.lang.Object
    • gameframework.motion.blocking.MoveBlockerRulesApplierDefaultImpl
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MoveBlockerRulesApplier

    public class MoveBlockerRulesApplierDefaultImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements MoveBlockerRulesApplier
    Take care of special blocking rules for your game. By default, a MoveBlocker always blocks a Movable. But you can change this behavior by sub-classing MoveBlockerRulesApplierDefaultImpl and implementing different behaviours for the moveBlockerRule methods, depending on which parameters you give to it. For example, in a typical Pacman game, a moveBlockerRule method could look like: 
     
 public void moveBlockerRule(Ghost ghost, Wall wall) throws IllegalMoveException {
   // The default case is when a ghost is active and not able to cross a
   // wall. As soon as the ghost has been eaten by Pacman, the ghost becomes
   // inactive and will cross walls to return to its jail in straight line.
   if (ghost.isActive()) {
     throw new IllegalMoveException();
   }
 }

    • Method Detail

      • moveValidationProcessing

        public boolean moveValidationProcessing(GameMovable movable,
                                        java.util.Vector<MoveBlocker> blockers)
        Description copied from interface: MoveBlockerRulesApplier
        This method checks if the movable can move according to the moveblockers in obs. If true, this means that no MoveBlocker blocks the way of the GameMovable.
        Specified by:
        moveValidationProcessing in interface MoveBlockerRulesApplier
        Parameters:
        movable - the movable to test
        blockers - the MoveBlocker vector
        Returns:
        true if the movable is allowed to move, false otherwise
        See Also:
        MoveBlockerRulesApplier.moveValidationProcessing(gameframework.motion.GameMovable, java.util.Vector)

        public void setGameData(GameData gameData)
